Excellent discussion thus far....I believe it is not solely or mostly a matter of generation divide of X vs Y but economic and family background play a major role as well. When your family background includes a high value for learning and economic resources, you are more likely to have access to technology and thus fit within a rapidly changing technology culture/environment. In every generation there is talk about the other generations and how different / better / worse they are. The goes back to the old Greeks, who talked about the younger generations and how disrespectful and greedy they are. I agree with Sherene, lot of it is media hype and I disagree with the opening statement of this discussion thread. When I joined the corporate world in HR there was a lot of talk about the 'No future' generation (punks, skin heads etc.). In my experience people want to be respected, want to work on interesting things, want to make a living and want direction/orientation for what is expected from them. These are human traits and are generation independent. Let's not forget, most of the technology and trendy things around us have been developed by baby boomers (not ignoring some younger outliers). The younger generations have grown up in this environment and just dealing with it and building on what they have been born into.

There are a lot of good opinions in these postings. My team at work is a mix of Gen X and Gen Y. They are highly productive individuals, but in each their own ways. I also believe it is false to say that one group is more creative than the other. They just express themselves differently. I often find that Gen X will acknowldge what another coworker will say and build upon that idea. So we end up with a concrete building block from which to jump off of. Members of Gen Y rarely (though high achieving ones know they should) acknowledge what their coworkers have said, and instead push off on their own direction. This sometimes creates a many blocks without a foundation. For example, members of Gen X seem to prefer a little more structure, have good verbal communication skills, and tend to be more paitent. Gen Y lacks the communication skills, want everything now, and are not as timid if knowledge is needed to be obtained. In my mind none of these are cons. Everything can be improved and thus having a good mix of both Gen X and Gen Y is what creates a succcessful group. My team is healthy mix of both, and those who don't write as well know who to leverage when publishing documents. In return, those who need help approaching others for information use the braver members of the team for ideas and help.

I also believe it is false to say that one group is more creative than the other. They just express themselves differently. I often find that Gen X will acknowldge what another coworker will say and build upon that idea. So we end up with a concrete building block from which to jump off of. Members of Gen Y rarely (though high achieving ones know they should) acknowledge what their coworkers have said, and instead push off on their own direction. This sometimes creates a many blocks without a foundation. For example, members of Gen X seem to prefer a little more structure, have good verbal communication skills, and tend to be more paitent. Everything can be improved and thus having a good mix of both Gen X and Gen Y is what creates a succcessful group. Input.threadtitle: The open talk but rational walk
Input.posts:
I would like to put forward that many executive / board level managers talk an open talk, but walk a rational walk. What I mean by this is that words like 'eco-system' and 'full stakeholder management' and 'triple bottom line' will be used internally and externally, and that the C-suite is very much exposed and therefore aware of the open system within which their corporations operate. However, in the day-to-day management of their businesses the emphasis is on a controllable, predictable management style, that provides scale and uniformity and not the fluidity even ambiguity that would be typical of an open system. So their walk, is a 'rational system' walk.

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Thanks for posting this question! Not sure if anyone here is enrolled in New Models of Business in Society (also currently offered on Coursera) but this question fits nicely into what we're learning there about changing the 'old story' of business. I hope to see lots of responses to this! There are so many great organizations in business today, that it's hard to single out any particular one. At the same time, there are no 'perfect' organizations either. I will put in a plug for what I deem to be a great model within the financial services sector in Canada: Credit Unions. Historically, Credit Unions were created to 'serve the under-served'; whether that was due to geographic, demographic or discriminatory neglect. More recently, in our competitive, hi-tech world where we struggle to define 'under-served', Credit Unions have sought to differentiate themselves based on Corporate Social Responsibility and value creation for members; a 'not-just-profit' model where success is shared by all members and stake-holders. This model has served Credit Unions and their members very well for many decades. Recently, following the GFC (Global Financial Crisis), regulators have buckled down on all financial institutions in a reactive attempt to close the gaps in regulatory oversight and intervention. This is not necessarily a bad thing, but where institutions with say $500M in assets are expected to manage the same regulatory load as institutions with 100's of billions in assets, the market begins to change. What we're seeing now is basically a shakeout: mergers with larger institutions, or the creation of service organizations that share executive staff/administrative services to buy smaller institutions a little more time. Small branches are closing in areas that were ignored by the big chartered banks, that only the Credit Union system would consider. The financial services landscape is changing dramatically. Is that a bad thing? For the consumer, I believe that it is. So, back to the original question that was posted: why do I think this is the best organization that exists? I don't, but I believe in the model: co-operative, socially responsible, and successfully creating value for the people it serves. Social responsibility may be becoming a more common value in the chartered banking world, but those values together to form a whole, are unique to the Credit Union system. Credit Unions will survive this shift, but I wonder what we'll lose in the process?
